==Chinese==
{{zh-forms}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|女|又|ls=ic|t1=woman|t2=hand}} – a woman with hands at the back (bronze inscriptions).

The oracle bone script forms are {{liushu|p|adj=1|nocap=1}}, showing a woman with hands crossed at the back, as opposed to {{och-l|女}} which depicts a woman clasping her hands in front of the body.

==Vietnamese==

===Han character===
{{vi-hantu|[[nô]], [[no]], [[nó]], [[nọ]]|rs=女02}}

# {{lb|vi|colloquial}} [[he]], [[she]], [[it]]

====Usage notes====
* Chữ Nôm.
* This is the common form of this character. The regular form is [[伮]].
* The term is ''de facto'' used to refer to any animal (including the human) in the third person, in a disrespectful manner. The use of the term to translate the English ''it'', or to refer to an inanimate object, is rather artificial, and mostly found in awkward (but common) translation of other languages.
